title: Culture Fit Homogeneity Trap
context: Companies hire for 'culture fit' to build cohesive teams and reduce friction. The intent is reasonable — teams that share values and communication styles work together more smoothly. But 'culture fit' is often a proxy for demographic and cognitive similarity. Interviewers unconsciously select candidates who look, think, and communicate like themselves. Over time, the organization becomes increasingly homogeneous. Dissenting viewpoints disappear. Groupthink sets in. The company loses the cognitive diversity needed to spot blind spots, challenge assumptions, and innovate. The very cohesion that culture fit creates becomes a vulnerability — the team agrees quickly but agrees on the wrong things.
hypothesis: Hiring for culture fit builds stronger, more cohesive teams.

chain.root: Prioritize culture fit in hiring decisions

children.label: Interviewers select candidates similar to themselves
Underrepresented candidates filtered out as 'not a fit'
Blind spots become organizational blind spots
Culture fit used as cover for discriminatory hiring
Employer brand suffers among diverse candidates

dontIf: Your 'culture fit' criteria can't be articulated as specific, measurable behaviors
Your interview panel lacks demographic diversity
ifYouMust: Replace 'culture fit' with 'culture add' — what new perspective does this person bring?
Define culture as specific values and behaviors, not vibes
Use structured interviews with rubrics to reduce bias
Track hiring demographics against culture fit scores to detect proxy discrimination

alternatives.name: Culture add hiring
alternatives.note: Hire for what's missing, not what's already there

alternatives.name: Values-based hiring
alternatives.note: Assess alignment with explicit values, not implicit social norms

alternatives.name: Structured behavioral interviews
alternatives.note: Evaluate specific competencies with standardized questions and rubrics
